As empirical data for mercury concentrations (MeHg) are limited for the majority of marine organisms of the food web from the study region (e.g., absence of MeHg data for killer whales precluded the MB-assessment for this species), we conducted a comparison (i.e. MB ratio) of projected MeHg concentrations for wild Chinook, chum and coho salmon species against the observed MeHg data reported for these species in coastal BC in 2003
31 . Therefore, based on the limited empirical MeHg data reported for these salmon species (i.e. Chinook, chum and coho) for a single year
31 , the model simulations showed systematically overprediction when compared to observed MeHg concentrations (Fig. S10 and Table S7). The lack of empirical MeHg data for most species/functional groups prevented a concerted assessment of the model bias and uncertainty. However, the accuracy of the simulations for the model was tested by comparing the model PCB projections in biota to empirical data and calculating 95% CI around the geometric mean of the MB, as an indication of the uncertainty of model predictions (Figs 6 and 7; Tables S5 and S6).
